natural problem:
A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
natural solution: The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t = 0.36"
and h1 : "\<forall> area_flag area_cross area_blue. area_cross + area_blue = t * area_flag"
shows  "\<forall> area_flag area_blue. area_blue = 0.02 * area_flag"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t = 0.36"
and h1 : "\<forall> area_flag area_cross area_blue. area_cross + area_blue = t * area_flag"
shows  "\<forall> area_flag area_blue. area_blue = 0.02 * area_flag"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that the total area of the cross and the blue region is 36% of the total flag area, find the area of the blue region if it is given that the area of the blue region is 2% of the total flag area.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area white_area :: real
assumes h0 : "flag_area = red_cross_area + blue_area + white_area"
and h1 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
and h2 : "blue_area = 0.02 * flag_area"
shows  "blue_area / flag_area * 100 = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area white_area :: real
assumes h0 : "flag_area = red_cross_area + blue_area + white_area"
and h1 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
and h2 : "blue_area = 0.02 * flag_area"
shows  "blue_area / flag_area * 100 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A flag consists of three areas: red cross area, blue area, and white area. The sum of the red cross area and the blue area is 36% of the flag area, and the blue area is 2% of the flag area. What percentage of the flag area is the blue area? The final answer is 2%.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
and h1 : "red_cross_area > 0"
and h2 : "blue_area > 0"
and h3 : "flag_area > 0"
shows  "blue_area = 0.02 * flag_area"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
and h1 : "red_cross_area > 0"
and h2 : "blue_area > 0"
and h3 : "flag_area > 0"
shows  "blue_area = 0.02 * flag_area"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There is a flag where the area of the red cross and the area of the blue region sum up to 36% of the total flag area. If the red cross area, blue area, and flag area are all positive, find the fraction of the flag area that the blue area takes up. The final answer is 2% of the flag area.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_area red_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area > 0"
and h1 : "red_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h2 : "blue_area = total_area - red_area"
and h3 : "blue_area = 0.02 * total_area"
shows  "blue_area / total_area * 100 = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_area red_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area > 0"
and h1 : "red_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h2 : "blue_area = total_area - red_area"
and h3 : "blue_area = 0.02 * total_area"
shows  "blue_area / total_area * 100 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a certain region, the total area is greater than 0. Red and blue areas cover this region. The red area covers 36% of the total area, while the blue area covers the remaining area. If the blue area is 2% of the total area, what percentage of the total area is covered by the blue area? The final answer is 2%.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "blue_area \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "red_cross_area \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "flag_area \<ge> 0"
and h3 : "red_cross_area + blue_area \<le> flag_area"
and h4 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
shows  "blue_area = 0.02 * flag_area"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "blue_area \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "red_cross_area \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "flag_area \<ge> 0"
and h3 : "red_cross_area + blue_area \<le> flag_area"
and h4 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
shows  "blue_area = 0.02 * flag_area"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that the area of a flag consists of a red cross and a blue area, with both the red cross area and blue area being non-negative, and the total area of the flag being non-negative, find the blue area if the combined area of the red cross and blue area is 36% of the flag's area. The final answer is 2% of the flag's area.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "flag_area > 0"
and h1 : "red_cross_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
and h2 : "blue_area = flag_area - red_cross_area"
shows  "blue_area / flag_area * 100 = 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes flag_area red_cross_area blue_area :: real
assumes h0 : "flag_area > 0"
and h1 : "red_cross_area = 0.36 * flag_area"
and h2 : "blue_area = flag_area - red_cross_area"
shows  "blue_area / flag_area * 100 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a flag with a total area greater than 0, the red cross area covers 36% of the flag area. Calculate the percentage of the flag area covered by the blue area. The final answer is 64%.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes blue_area cross_area total_area :: real
assumes h0 : "cross_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h1 : "blue_area = 0.02 * total_area"
and h2 : "blue_area + 4 * ((total_area - cross_area) / 4) = cross_area"
shows  "blue_area / total_area = 0.02"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes blue_area cross_area total_area :: real
assumes h0 : "cross_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h1 : "blue_area = 0.02 * total_area"
and h2 : "blue_area + 4 * ((total_area - cross_area) / 4) = cross_area"
shows  "blue_area / total_area = 0.02"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a certain region, the cross-shaped area occupies $36\%$ of the total area, while the blue area occupies $2\%$ of the total area. If the blue area plus the remaining area divided equally into $4$ parts equals the cross-shaped area, find the ratio of the blue area to the total area. The final answer is $0.02$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_cross_area blue_area total_area :: real
assumes h0 : "0 < red_cross_area"
and h1 : "0 < blue_area"
and h2 : "0 < total_area"
and h3 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h4 : "blue_area = total_area * (1 - 0.36) * 0.25"
shows  "blue_area / total_area * 100 = 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_cross_area blue_area total_area :: real
assumes h0 : "0 < red_cross_area"
and h1 : "0 < blue_area"
and h2 : "0 < total_area"
and h3 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h4 : "blue_area = total_area * (1 - 0.36) * 0.25"
shows  "blue_area / total_area * 100 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a certain region, the total area is represented by "total_area", the area covered by the Red Cross is represented by "red_cross_area" and the area covered by the Blue Cross is represented by "blue_area". Both the Red Cross and Blue Cross areas are positive. The Red Cross and Blue Cross together cover 36% of the total area. The Blue Cross area is equal to 25% of the remaining area not covered by the Red Cross or Blue Cross. What percentage of the total area is covered by the Blue Cross? The final answer is 2%.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_cross_area blue_area total_area :: real
assumes h0 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h1 : "blue_area = 0.02 * total_area"
shows  "red_cross_area = 0.34 * total_area"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_cross_area blue_area total_area :: real
assumes h0 : "red_cross_area + blue_area = 0.36 * total_area"
and h1 : "blue_area = 0.02 * total_area"
shows  "red_cross_area = 0.34 * total_area"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a certain region, the combined area of the Red Cross and Blue Cross territories is equal to 36% of the total area of the region. If the Blue Cross territory makes up 2% of the total area, what percentage of the total area is occupied by the Red Cross territory? The final answer is 34%.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes blue :: real and red :: real and white :: real
assumes h0 : "blue + red = 0.36 * (blue + red + white)"
and h1 : "red = 2 * blue"
shows  "blue = 0.02 * (blue + red + white)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A square flag has a red cross of uniform width with a blue square in the center on a white background as shown. (The cross is symmetric with respect to each of the diagonals of the square.) If the entire cross (both the red arms and the blue center) takes up 36% of the area of the flag, what percent of the area of the flag is blue?
[asy] unitsize(2.5 cm);  pair[] A, B, C; real t = 0.2;  A[1] = (0,0); A[2] = (1,0); A[3] = (1,1); A[4] = (0,1); B[1] = (t,0); B[2] = (1 - t,0); B[3] = (1,t); B[4] = (1,1 - t); B[5] = (1 - t,1); B[6] = (t,1); B[7] = (0,1 - t); B[8] = (0,t); C[1] = extension(B[1],B[4],B[7],B[2]); C[2] = extension(B[3],B[6],B[1],B[4]); C[3] = extension(B[5],B[8],B[3],B[6]); C[4] = extension(B[7],B[2],B[5],B[8]);  fill(C[1]--C[2]--C[3]--C[4]--cycle,blue); fill(A[1]--B[1]--C[1]--C[4]--B[8]--cycle,red); fill(A[2]--B[3]--C[2]--C[1]--B[2]--cycle,red); fill(A[3]--B[5]--C[3]--C[2]--B[4]--cycle,red); fill(A[4]--B[7]--C[4]--C[3]--B[6]--cycle,red);  draw(A[1]--A[2]--A[3]--A[4]--cycle); draw(B[1]--B[4]); draw(B[2]--B[7]); draw(B[3]--B[6]); draw(B[5]--B[8]); [/asy]
$\text{(A)}\ 0.5\qquad\text{(B)}\ 1\qquad\text{(C)}\ 2\qquad\text{(D)}\ 3\qquad\text{(E)}\ 6$
 The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The diagram can be quartered as shown:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(5,4)); draw((0,4)--(4,0)); draw((1,5)--(5,1)); draw((0,0)--(5,5),dotted); draw((0,5)--(5,0),dotted); [/asy]and reassembled into two smaller squares of side $k$, each of which looks like this:[asy] draw((0,0)--(0,5)--(5,5)--(5,0)--(0,0)); draw((0,1)--(4,1)--(4,5)); draw((1,0)--(1,4)--(5,4)); label("blue",(0.5,0.5)); label("blue",(4.5,4.5)); label("red",(0.5,4.5)); label("red",(4.5,0.5)); label("white",(2.5,2.5)); [/asy]The border in this figure is the former cross, which still occupies 36% of the area.
 Therefore the inner square occupies 64% of the area, from which we deduce that it is $0.8k \times 0.8k$, and that one blue square must be $0.1k\times 0.1k=0.01k^2$ or 1% each.
 Thus the blue area is $\boxed{2}\%$ of the total.
 *)

theorem
fixes blue :: real and red :: real and white :: real
assumes h0 : "blue + red = 0.36 * (blue + red + white)"
and h1 : "red = 2 * blue"
shows  "blue = 0.02 * (blue + red + white)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that the sum of blue and red represents 36% of the total (blue, red, and white), and the red is twice the blue, find the percentage of the total that the blue represents. The final answer is 2%.
